GC_Renewal.zwo.description: Recovery. Regeneration. Renewal. It is just as important at the hard stuff. Fast cadence efforts facilitate flushing the legs without fatiguing them. Today is an active recovery day, NO HARD EFFORTS!
GC_Renewal.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Ruckus.zwo.name: Ruckus
GC_Ruckus.zwo.description: Stand up and make some noise... Or power! A mix of standing and sitting intervals that are designed to help you speak loudly without saying a word!
GC_Ruckus.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Serrated.zwo.name: Serrated
GC_Serrated.zwo.description: Intervals that come up to a very sharp point, looking like a serrated knife upon post-workout review. This workout will make you sharp for race day, ready to tackle the surges of terrain and competition.
GC_Serrated.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Sneaky.zwo.name: Sneaky
GC_Sneaky.zwo.description: The kind of workout that "sneaks" up on you, especially that last interval.
GC_Sneaky.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Spaded_Sweetie.zwo.name: Spaded Sweetie
GC_Spaded_Sweetie.zwo.description: The Spaded Sweetie starts off with a 15 minute warm up to prime the engines and ready the mind.  Then, we move into a spade interval set starting off very hard, but short, and gradually reducing the intensity while upping the time... Only to go back up again!  From there, we will move into a progressive over/under sweet spot interval featuring changes in cadence and intensity that culminates in a 1min FULL GAS effort! This is a tough workout, but feautures a lot of quality time at VO2 and threshold.
GC_Spaded_Sweetie.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Tenacity.zwo.name: Tenacity
GC_Tenacity.zwo.description: This workout will ask a lot of you. But you didn't get to this point without a lot of Tenacity. So let that fitness shine through today.
GC_Tenacity.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Thew.zwo.name: Thew
GC_Thew.zwo.description: A hard workout that requires a lot of "strength" both physically and mentally to accomplish. Thew, in case you didn't know it, is a fancy word meaning, "muscular strength." You learned something new and got more fit. Hard to beat that!
GC_Thew.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Tine.zwo.name: Tine
GC_Tine.zwo.description: Intervals that gradually come to a "sharp point," just like the Tines on a fork!
GC_Tine.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Uphill_Battle.zwo.name: Uphill Battle
GC_Uphill_Battle.zwo.description: Another one of those workouts that gets harder as it goes on, making it feel like you are in an "uphill battle."
GC_Uphill_Battle.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_What_Goes_Up_Must_Come_Down.zwo.name: What Goes Up, Must Come Down
GC_What_Goes_Up_Must_Come_Down.zwo.description: The duration goes up. The intensity comes down. Simple enough, right?
GC_What_Goes_Up_Must_Come_Down.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Yellow_Unicorn.zwo.name: Yellow Unicorn
GC_Yellow_Unicorn.zwo.description: All the Unicorn workouts are based off of the visual spectrum (Red, Orange, Yellow, Green, Blue, Indigo, Violet (purple)) with the same order of easiest to hardest.  So, Red Unicorn features the least training load, Orange Unicorn the second, etc.
GC_Yellow_Unicorn.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

Pre-Training_Plan.zwo.name: Zone Benchmarking
Pre-Training_Plan.zwo.description: Introductory workout to be done prior to starting a training plan. This should be done after a ramp test. The focus today is making sure your FTP is accurate from the ramp test. Please adjust your FTP up or down based on how each zone feels today.
Pre-Training_Plan.zwo.author: Zwift

GC_Devedeset.zwo.name: Devedeset Lite
GC_Devedeset.zwo.description: Training in the power zone just below your functional threshold power (FTP) is a super effective and efficient way to raise your fitness - this is also called the 'sweet spot zone. Today's workout is this plan's introduction to that zone. After a warm-up, we'll go into 2, 8min long sweet spot intervals with 3min of rest in between, then cool down.
GC_Devedeset.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Halvfems.zwo.name: Halvfems Lite
GC_Halvfems.zwo.description: Another key aspect of sweet spot training is spending a lot of quality time in the zone without building up undue fatigue. This allows for better repeatability and increased training density throughout a training block. With that said, we'll progress our sweet spot-focused workout today. After a warm-up, we'll go into 2, 10min long sweet spot intervals with 4min of rest in between, then cool down. This is 2min more than last week. You got this!
GC_Halvfems.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Novanta.zwo.name: Novanta Lite
GC_Novanta.zwo.description: The sweet spot zone training zone is between 84% to 97% of FTP. The sweet spot workouts in this plan thread the needle at 90% FTP. Today we'll continue to progress our sweet spot-focused workout. After a warm-up, we'll go into 2, 12min long sweet spot intervals with 4min of rest in between, then cool down. This is another 2min more than last week. Look at you go!
GC_Novanta.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Orange_Unicorn.zwo.name: Orange Unicorn Lite
GC_Orange_Unicorn.zwo.description: Making workouts less monotonous and fun is a crucial aspect of indoor training. Over/unders is an excellent way to accomplish this. Today's workout is the next step in our over/under workout series. After a warm-up, we'll go into 2 sets of 6x (2min under and 30sec over), then cool down. We're pushing the under this week by another minute, but I know you are up for it!
GC_Orange_Unicorn.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Purple_Unicorn.zwo.name: Purple Unicorn Lite
GC_Purple_Unicorn.zwo.description: You've made it to the most challenging unicorn workout of Build Me Up Lite, congrats to you! Today, we're adding another challenging step to the intervals in the form of another 30sec over interval. So, you'll do 2min under, 1min over, and another 30sec over! Is it mean to do that? Maybe... but your fitness will thank you later! Get after it today!
GC_Purple_Unicorn.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Red_Unicorn.zwo.name: Red Unicorn Lite
GC_Red_Unicorn.zwo.description: Going above and below functional threshold power (FTP) is a great way to increase the training impact of a workout - this is also known as 'over/unders.' Today's workout is the first of this plan's progressive over/under workout series. After a warm-up, we'll go into 2 sets of 6x (1min under and 30sec over), then cool down.
GC_Red_Unicorn.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Sneaky.zwo.name: Sneaky Lite
GC_Sneaky.zwo.description: Sneaky, as the name would imply, is the kind of workout that 'sneaks' up on you, especially that last interval when the legs are a bit fatigued already. Today, after the warm up, we'll do 4 intervals consisting of 3min moderate, and 1 min hard, then cool down.
GC_Sneaky.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

GC_Yellow_Unicorn.zwo.name: Yellow Unicorn Lite
GC_Yellow_Unicorn.zwo.description: Another week, another unicorn workout! Today, we'll keep the under portion the same as last week but progress the over portion by 30sec! So, after a warm-up, we'll do 6x (2min under and 1min over), then cool down. Get ready to push yourself a bit more today, but you are strong!
GC_Yellow_Unicorn.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

1_1_Steady_Climbing_1.zwo.name: Week 1.1 - Steady Climbing #1
1_1_Steady_Climbing_1.zwo.description:
Today's session focuses on simulating the demands of extended climbing.

The climb starts at the lower end of zone 3 and finishes in zone 4. But you will be targeting a cadence similar to climbing.

When performing the 4 x 5min intervals, position yourself on the bike as you would climbing seated.
1_1_Steady_Climbing_1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

1_2_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.name: Week 1.2 - Climbing - Free ride
1_2_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.description:
Today is about endurance and climbing. 

Zwift provides us with the perfect playground to experience long climbs. The aim today is to climb as many meters as your available time allows you. Try to make today your longest ride for the week. It doesn't have to be full of high intensity climbing. Go off your own sensations and ride as you feel.

There are a range of hilly loops available. Choose the course suited to your climbing aims and time available. Enjoy your ride!
1_2_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

1_3_Tempo_15min__Target_rpm_1.zwo.name: Week 1.3 - Tempo 15min / Target rpm #1
1_3_Tempo_15min__Target_rpm_1.zwo.description:
Tempo riding is a great way to improve your aerobic efficiency. Today's session consists of 2 x 15 minute tempo efforts. 

However, to focus more on muscular endurance, the target cadence starts at 75rpm and increases by 5rpm every 5min.
1_3_Tempo_15min__Target_rpm_1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

1_4_Anaerobic_Endurance_4_x_60sec.zwo.name: Week 1.4 - Anaerobic Endurance 4 x 60sec
1_4_Anaerobic_Endurance_4_x_60sec.zwo.description:
After completing a good warm up the main sets consist of 4 x 60 seconds at 121%FTP, with 3min recovery.

Anaerobic Endurance involves high cadence and big power, along with the ability to resist fatigue.

Throughout each 60sec interval observe your cadence and heart rate. Is your cadence dropping with fatigue and your heart rate rising?
1_4_Anaerobic_Endurance_4_x_60sec.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

1_5_Aerobic_12_s__1.zwo.name: Week 1.5 - Aerobic 12's #1
1_5_Aerobic_12_s__1.zwo.description:
Aerobic Endurance workouts are aimed at improving your efficiency at lower intensity levels. 
Training your muscles to access fat as its main fuel source and preserve your precious glycogen stores for the finale.

After warming up, you will be completing 3 x 12min aerobic efforts with 3min recovery. 

Keep an eye on your heart rate response to the sustained power. Are you achieving the same heart rate in the third effort as the first?
1_5_Aerobic_12_s__1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

1_6_Endurance_1.zwo.name: Week 1.6 - Endurance #1
1_6_Endurance_1.zwo.description:
After warming up, the focus is on improving your aerobic endurance.

The main set consists of a steady aerobic effort with target power at 70%. However, every 5 minutes you will perform a 10 second surge at 130%.
1_6_Endurance_1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

2_1_Steady_Climbing_1.zwo.name: Week 2.1 - Steady Climbing #1
2_1_Steady_Climbing_1.zwo.description:
Today's session focuses on simulating the demands of extended climbing.

The climb starts at the lower end of zone 3 and finishes in zone 4. But you will be targeting a cadence similar to climbing.

When performing the 4 x 5min intervals, position yourself on the bike as you would climbing seated.
2_1_Steady_Climbing_1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

2_2_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.name: Week 2.2 - Climbing - Free ride
2_2_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.description:
Today is about endurance and climbing. 

Zwift provides us with the perfect playground to experience long climbs. The aim today is to climb as many meters as your available time allows you. Try to make today your longest ride for the week. It doesn't have to be full of high intensity climbing. Go off your own sensations and ride as you feel.

There are a range of hilly loops available. Choose the course suited to your climbing aims and time available. Enjoy your ride!
2_2_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

2_3_Anaerobic_Endurance_6_x_60sec.zwo.name: Week 2.3 - Anaerobic Endurance 6 x 60sec
2_3_Anaerobic_Endurance_6_x_60sec.zwo.description:
After completing a good warm up the main sets consist of 6 x 60 seconds at 121%FTP, with 3min recovery.

Anaerobic Endurance involves high cadence and big power, along with the ability to resist fatigue.

Throughout each 60sec interval observe your cadence and heart rate. Is your cadence dropping with fatigue and your heart rate rising?
2_3_Anaerobic_Endurance_6_x_60sec.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

2_4_Tempo_20min___Target_rpm__2.zwo.name: Week 2.4 - Tempo 20min / Target rpm #2
2_4_Tempo_20min___Target_rpm__2.zwo.description:
Tempo riding is a great way to improve your aerobic efficiency. Today's session consists of 2 x 20 minute tempo efforts. 

However, to focus more on muscular endurance, the target cadence starts at 75rpm and increases by 5rpm every 5min.
2_4_Tempo_20min___Target_rpm__2.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

2_5_Aerobic_12_s__2.zwo.name: Week 2.5 - Aerobic 12's #2
2_5_Aerobic_12_s__2.zwo.description:
Aerobic Endurance workouts are aimed at improving your efficiency at lower intensity levels. 
Training your muscles to access fat as its main fuel source and preserve your precious glycogen stores for the finale.

After warming up, you will be completing 4 x 12min aerobic efforts with 3min recovery. 

Keep an eye on your heart rate response to the sustained power. Are you achieving the same heart rate in the third effort as the first?
2_5_Aerobic_12_s__2.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

2_6_Endurance_1.zwo.name: Week 2.6 - Endurance #1
2_6_Endurance_1.zwo.description:
After warming up, the focus is on improving your aerobic endurance.

The main set consists of a steady aerobic effort with target power at 70%. However, every 5 minutes you will perform a 10 second surge at 130%.
2_6_Endurance_1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

3_1_Progressive_Climb_1.zwo.name: Week 3.1 - Progressive Climb #1
3_1_Progressive_Climb_1.zwo.description:
3 climbs of 11 minutes in duration today, but each one is climbed using a different cadence.

Just like a climb outdoors, the required power will increase throughout the 11min.
3_1_Progressive_Climb_1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

3_2_Anaerobic_Capacity_Hills__1.zwo.name: Week 3.2 - Anaerobic Capacity Hills #1
3_2_Anaerobic_Capacity_Hills__1.zwo.description:
Increasing your anaerobic capacity will help you become a stronger cyclist.

Anaerobic energy can be used for a short burst at a higher power output than your FTP. To improve your anaerobic capacity we need to produce high power efforts between 30sec and 3min. 

In this session we replicate AC intervals performed on a climb by adding a target rpm. The climb starts out steady enough, before ramping up to the finish with high power.
3_2_Anaerobic_Capacity_Hills__1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

3_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.name: Week 3.3 - Climbing - Free ride
3_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.description:
Today is about endurance and climbing. 

Zwift provides us with the perfect playground to experience long climbs. The aim today is to climb as many meters as your available time allows you. Try to make today your longest ride for the week. It doesn't have to be full of high intensity climbing. Go off your own sensations and ride as you feel.

There are a range of hilly loops available. Choose the course suited to your climbing aims and time available. Enjoy your ride!
3_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

3_4_Sub_Threshold__1.zwo.name: Week 3.4 - Sub Threshold #1
3_4_Sub_Threshold__1.zwo.description:
To build endurance and aerobic efficiency we need to perform long steady efforts. Today's session comprises of 2 x 15 minute Sub Threshold efforts. 

After opeNing the interval with a 30 second zone 5 surge, the remaining 15 minutes will gradually increase over the duration of the effort.

Observe how much this increase in power affects your heart rate.
3_4_Sub_Threshold__1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

3_5_Tempo_15min___Target_rpm__3.zwo.name: Week 3.5 - Tempo 15min / Target rpm #3
3_5_Tempo_15min___Target_rpm__3.zwo.description: Tempo riding is a great way to improve your aerobic efficiency. Today's session consists of 3 x 15 minute tempo efforts. However, to focus more on muscular endurance, the target cadence starts at 75rpm and increases by 5rpm every 5min.
3_5_Tempo_15min___Target_rpm__3.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

3_6_Endurance__2.zwo.name: Week 3.6 - Endurance #2
3_6_Endurance__2.zwo.description:
Long, low intensity efforts aren't the only way to build endurance. By incorporating short surges into a steady effort you will increase your oxygen uptake and training stimulus.

Completing a low intensity effort with a surge every 4 minutes should feel comfortable, but the constant change in power and surging, will provide you with big gains in endurance.
3_6_Endurance__2.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

4_1_Progressive_Climb_1.zwo.name: Week 4.1 - Progressive Climb #1
4_1_Progressive_Climb_1.zwo.description:
3 climbs of 11 minutes in duration today, but each one is climbed using a different cadence.

Just like a climb outdoors, the required power will increase throughout the 11min.
4_1_Progressive_Climb_1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

4_2_Tempo_15min___Target_rpm__3.zwo.name: Week 4.2 - Tempo 15min / Target rpm #3
4_2_Tempo_15min___Target_rpm__3.zwo.description: Tempo riding is a great way to improve your aerobic efficiency. Today's session consists of 3 x 15 minute tempo efforts. However, to focus more on muscular endurance, the target cadence starts at 75rpm and increases by 5rpm every 5min.
4_2_Tempo_15min___Target_rpm__3.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

4_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.name: Week 4.3 - Climbing - Free ride
4_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.description:
Today is about endurance and climbing. 

Zwift provides us with the perfect playground to experience long climbs. The aim today is to climb as many meters as your available time allows you. Try to make today your longest ride for the week. It doesn't have to be full of high intensity climbing. Go off your own sensations and ride as you feel.

There are a range of hilly loops available. Choose the course suited to your climbing aims and time available. Enjoy your ride!
4_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

4_4_Anaerobic_Capacity_Hills__2.zwo.name: Week 4.4 - Anaerobic Capacity Hills #2
4_4_Anaerobic_Capacity_Hills__2.zwo.description:
Increasing your anaerobic capacity will help you become a stronger cyclist. Anaerobic energy can be used for a short burst at a higher power output than your FTP. 

To improve your anaerobic capacity we need to produce high power efforts between 30sec and 3min. In this session we replicate AC intervals performed on a climb by adding a target rpm. The climb starts out steady enough, before ramping up to the finish with high power.
4_4_Anaerobic_Capacity_Hills__2.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

4_5_Tempo_with_30sec_spike__1.zwo.name: Week 4.5 - Tempo with 30sec spike #1
4_5_Tempo_with_30sec_spike__1.zwo.description:
Steady Tempo efforts are great. But by incorporating 30 second high intensity efforts into them, you will improve your body's ability to work aerobically for long periods.

Today's sessions consists of 2 x 12 minute Tempo efforts with a 30 second surge every 3.5 minutes.
4_5_Tempo_with_30sec_spike__1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

4_6_Endurance__2.zwo.name: Week 4.6 - Endurance #2
4_6_Endurance__2.zwo.description:
Long, low intensity efforts aren't the only way to build endurance. By incorporating short surges into a steady effort you will increase your oxygen uptake and training stimulus.

Completing a low intensity effort with a surge every 4 minutes should feel comfortable, but the constant change in power and surging, will provide you with big gains in endurance.
4_6_Endurance__2.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

5_1_13min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.name: Week 5.1 - 13min Progressive Climb
5_1_13min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.description:
3 climbs of 13 minutes in duration today, but each one is climbed using a different cadence. But as the power ramps up between steps, you self select your cadence before returning to the set cadence.

Just like a climb outdoors, the required power will increase throughout the 13 minutes. Culminating with 1 min above threshold at the top of the climb.

Position yourself on the bike as you would on a long climb.
5_1_13min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

5_2_Sub_Threshold__2.zwo.name: Week 5.2 - Sub Threshold #2
5_2_Sub_Threshold__2.zwo.description:
To build endurance and aerobic efficiency we need to perform long steady efforts. Today's session comprises of 3 x 8 minute Sub Threshold efforts. 

After opening the interval with a 30 second zone 5 surge, the remaining 7.5 minutes will gradually increase in power over the duration of the effort. Observe how much this increase in power affects your heart rate.
5_2_Sub_Threshold__2.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

5_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.name: Week 5.3 - Climbing - Free ride
5_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.description:
Today is about endurance and climbing. 

Zwift provides us with the perfect playground to experience long climbs. The aim today is to climb as many meters as your available time allows you. Try to make today your longest ride for the week. It doesn't have to be full of high intensity climbing. Go off your own sensations and ride as you feel.

There are a range of hilly loops available. Choose the course suited to your climbing aims and time available. Enjoy your ride!
5_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

5_4_Anaerobic_Capacity_1min___2min.zwo.name: Week 5.4 - Anaerobic Capacity 1min & 2min
5_4_Anaerobic_Capacity_1min___2min.zwo.description:
This is a very high level of intensity that requires mental and physical perseverance.

As well as improving your ability to produce sustained power above threshold, AC training will also improve your ability to recover from high intensity efforts and repeat them again and again.

With 5 x 2min efforts followed by 3 x 1min efforts, you will need to stay focused today!
5_4_Anaerobic_Capacity_1min___2min.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

5_5_Tempo_with_30sec_spike__2.zwo.name: Week 5.5 - Tempo with 30sec spike #2
5_5_Tempo_with_30sec_spike__2.zwo.description:
Steady Tempo efforts are great. But by incorporating 30 second high intensity efforts into them, you will improve your body's ability to work aerobically for long periods. 

Today's sessions consists of 2 x 16 minute Tempo efforts with a 30 second surge every 3.5 minutes.
5_5_Tempo_with_30sec_spike__2.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

5_6_Endurance__3.zwo.name: Week 5.6 - Endurance #3
5_6_Endurance__3.zwo.description:
Endurance sessions are the ideal time to focus on improving your pedaling. Power is not the focus in this session: 

Throughout today's endurance ride we will be increasing the focus on your cardiovascular endurance, by challenging your ability to pedal at a high cadence. A fun session that includes a range of high rpm intervals.
5_6_Endurance__3.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

6_1_13min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.name: Week 6.1 - 13min Progressive Climb
6_1_13min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.description:
3 climbs of 13 minutes in duration today, but each one is climbed using a different cadence. But as the power ramps up between steps, you self select your cadence before returning to the set cadence.

Just like a climb outdoors, the required power will increase throughout the 13 minutes. Culminating with 1 min above threshold at the top of the climb.

Position yourself on the bike as you would on a long climb.
6_1_13min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

6_2_AC___Sweet_Spot__1.zwo.name: Week 6.2 - AC + Sweet Spot #1
6_2_AC___Sweet_Spot__1.zwo.description:
The aim today is to both work on your Anaerobic Capacity, and to also improve your aerobic efficiency.

We do this by completing 5 x 2min AC intervals, before finishing with a 10min Sweet Spot effort. By depleting your carbohydrate stores with the AC intervals, the 10min Sweet Spot effort may not be as comfortable as it should be!
6_2_AC___Sweet_Spot__1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

6_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.name: Week 6.3 - Climbing - Free ride
6_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.description:
Today is about endurance and climbing. 

Zwift provides us with the perfect playground to experience long climbs. The aim today is to climb as many meters as your available time allows you. Try to make today your longest ride for the week. It doesn't have to be full of high intensity climbing. Go off your own sensations and ride as you feel.

There are a range of hilly loops available. Choose the course suited to your climbing aims and time available. Enjoy your ride!
6_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

6_4_Max_Aerobic_Climb__3.zwo.name: Week 6.4 - Max Aerobic Climb #3
6_4_Max_Aerobic_Climb__3.zwo.description:
With these max Aerobic efforts we are looking to simulate climbing. This is achieved by riding with a lower cadence, out of the saddle.

After warming up complete the following;
3 x 3min @ 109% with 3min recovery
10min recovery
3 x 2min @ 115% with 4min recovery.

During the intervals ride out of the saddle as much as possible. It's ok to sit occasionally for 10-20 at a time if needed.
6_4_Max_Aerobic_Climb__3.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

6_5_Sweet_Spot_12.zwo.name: Week 6.5 - Sweet Spot 12
6_5_Sweet_Spot_12.zwo.description:
There is no getting away from the benefit of longer steady efforts. To improve the stimulus of this type of training even further, these are the perfect prelude to finish with repeated, high power, short efforts.

Today we have 2 x 12min Sweet Spot efforts finished with 4 x 1min high cadence, threshold intervals.
6_5_Sweet_Spot_12.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

6_6_Endurance__3.zwo.name: Week 5.6 - Endurance #3
6_6_Endurance__3.zwo.description:
Endurance sessions are the ideal time to focus on improving your pedaling. Power is not the focus in this session: 

Throughout today's endurance ride we will be increasing the focus on your cardiovascular endurance, by challenging your ability to pedal at a high cadence. A fun session that includes a range of high rpm intervals.
6_6_Endurance__3.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

7_1_26min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.name: Week 7.1 - 26min Progressive Climb
7_1_26min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.description:
2 climbs of 26 minutes in duration today, but each one is climbed using a different cadence. But as the power ramps up between steps, you self select your cadence before returning to the set cadence.

Just like a climb outdoors, the required power will increase throughout the 26 minutes. Culminating with 1 min above threshold at the top of the climb.

Position yourself on the bike as you would on a long climb.
7_1_26min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

7_2_AC___Sweet_Spot__2.zwo.name: Week 7.2 - AC + Sweet Spot #2
7_2_AC___Sweet_Spot__2.zwo.description:
The aim today is to both work on your Anaerobic Capacity, and to also improve your aerobic efficiency. We do this by completing 6 x 2min AC intervals, before finishing with a 5min Sweet Spot effort. 

By depleting your carbohydrate stores with the AC intervals, the 5min Sweet Spot effort may not be as comfortable as it should be!
7_2_AC___Sweet_Spot__2.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

7_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.name: Week 7.3 - Climbing - Free ride
7_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.description:
Today is about endurance and climbing. 

Zwift provides us with the perfect playground to experience long climbs. The aim today is to climb as many meters as your available time allows you. Try to make today your longest ride for the week. It doesn't have to be full of high intensity climbing. Go off your own sensations and ride as you feel.

There are a range of hilly loops available. Choose the course suited to your climbing aims and time available. Enjoy your ride!
7_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

7_4_Max_Aerobic__5.zwo.name: Week 7.4 - Max Aerobic #5
7_4_Max_Aerobic__5.zwo.description:
After a good warm up, prepare yourself for some hard Max Aerobic intervals.

But the good news is the intensity does decrease across the efforts!

The 1st effort is 4min @ 120%
Then 2 x 3min efforts @ 112%
Followed by 2x 2min efforts @ 109%.
7_4_Max_Aerobic__5.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

7_5_Sweet_Spot_15.zwo.name: Week 7.5 - Sweet Spot 15
7_5_Sweet_Spot_15.zwo.description:
There is no getting away from the benefit of longer steady efforts. To improve the stimulus of this type of training even further, these are the perfect prelude to finish with repeated, high power, short efforts. 

Today we have a 15min Sweet Spot effort finished with 8 x 1min high cadence, threshold intervals.
7_5_Sweet_Spot_15.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

7_6_Endurance__4.zwo.name: Week 7.6 - Endurance #4
7_6_Endurance__4.zwo.description:
Building endurance doesn't just involve long, low power efforts. In this session we challenge your aerobic energy pathways with a range of efforts.

Opening with a 10min Zone 2 effort, we build into a some neuromuscular work, before finishing with a Zone 3 effort that starts at the top of the range and gradually decreases.
7_6_Endurance__4.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

8_1_26min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.name: Week 8.1 - 26min Progressive Climb
8_1_26min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.description:
2 climbs of 26 minutes in duration today, but each one is climbed using a different cadence. But as the power ramps up between steps, you self select your cadence before returning to the set cadence.

Just like a climb outdoors, the required power will increase throughout the 26 minutes. Culminating with 1 min above threshold at the top of the climb.

Position yourself on the bike as you would on a long climb.
8_1_26min_Progressive_Climb.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

8_2_Max_Aerobic_6_x_2min_30sec.zwo.name: Week 8.2 - Max Aerobic 6 x 2min 30sec
8_2_Max_Aerobic_6_x_2min_30sec.zwo.description:
Warm up well including 1min efforts in Zones 3,4 & 6.
Followed by;
6 x 2min 30sec @ 113%, with 2min 30sec recovery.
Cool down.
8_2_Max_Aerobic_6_x_2min_30sec.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

8_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.name: Week 8.3 - Climbing - Free ride
8_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.description:
Today is about endurance and climbing. 

Zwift provides us with the perfect playground to experience long climbs. The aim today is to climb as many meters as your available time allows you. Try to make today your longest ride for the week. It doesn't have to be full of high intensity climbing. Go off your own sensations and ride as you feel.

There are a range of hilly loops available. Choose the course suited to your climbing aims and time available. Enjoy your ride!
8_3_Climbing_-_Free_ride.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

8_4_AC_Intervals__1.zwo.name: Week 8.4 - AC Intervals #1
8_4_AC_Intervals__1.zwo.description:
This is a very high level of intensity that requires mental and physical perseverance.

Not only is it important to increase your ability to produce short, high powered efforts, so to is the importance of being able to repeat these efforts with little recovery.

In today's session the efforts get shorted, but the power increases.
8_4_AC_Intervals__1.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

8_5_Sweet_Spot_20.zwo.name: Week 8.5 - Sweet Spot 20
8_5_Sweet_Spot_20.zwo.description:
There is no getting away from the benefit of longer steady efforts. To improve the stimulus of this type of training even further, these are the perfect prelude to finish with repeated, high power, short efforts. 

Today we have a 20min Sweet Spot effort finished with 5 x 1min high cadence, threshold intervals.
8_5_Sweet_Spot_20.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

8_6_Endurance__4.zwo.name: Week 8.6 - Endurance #4
8_6_Endurance__4.zwo.description:
Building endurance doesn't just involve long, low power efforts. In this session we challenge your aerobic energy pathways with a range of efforts.

Opening with a 10min Zone 2 effort, we build into a some neuromuscular work, before finishing with a Zone 3 effort that starts at the top of the range and gradually decreases.
8_6_Endurance__4.zwo.author: Kevin Poulton

8wkRaceDay_1_1.zwo.name: Week 1.1 - Strength Training
8wkRaceDay_1_1.zwo.description: Start with a good warm up. Then 4 x 5 mins at FTP with 5 mins recovery between efforts, spin your legs easily for 10 minutes then 6 x 1 minute Upper Z6 power efforts with 2 minutes recovery in between - spin your legs out for 10 minutes then finally 10 x 15 second max sprint efforts with 45 seconds rest inbetweeen efforts.
8wkRaceDay_1_1.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_1_2.zwo.name: Week 1.2 - Zone 1 Ride
8wkRaceDay_1_2.zwo.description:
This is predominantly a fat burning ride - low efforts which will build and create a far greater mitochondrial density. Which carries more oxygen to the working muscles later... more easy riding will support the hard workouts nicely.
High Cadence! Up Up Up! - LOW POWER - FAST BREATHING
8wkRaceDay_1_2.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_1_3.zwo.name: Week 1.3 - Split 2/3
8wkRaceDay_1_3.zwo.description: This session is best done indoors on the trainer (A split session, Zone 2 followed by Zone 3). Watch the rpm's change to activate different energy systems and work the legs and lungs.  A cardio workout followed by a leg workout. No recovery between the efforts, so straight into the Zone 3 block from the 30 mins @ zone 2
8wkRaceDay_1_3.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_1_4.zwo.name: Week 1.4 - Hill Reps
8wkRaceDay_1_4.zwo.description:
warm up - 15 min...4 x 5 min reps with 5mins recovery between each rep.
remain seated whilst climbing. . Idea for today is to not raise heart rates too high but concentrate pressing down hardfrom tops of thighs, keeping a strict style working the core. Keep the burning sensations going. strengthening your ankles, knees and hips. Kind of a GYM session on the bike.  Perhaps do the last one at full speed to flood your body with the lactate.
8wkRaceDay_1_4.zwo.author: J.Doe

8wkRaceDay_2_1.zwo.name: Week 2.1 - Strength Training
8wkRaceDay_2_1.zwo.description: Start with a good warm up. warm up - 15 min...4 x 5 min reps with 5mins recovery between each rep.

Keep the burning sensations going. strengthening your ankles, knees and hips. Kind of a GYM session on the bike.  Perhaps do the last one at full speed to flood your body with the lactate.

8wkRaceDay_4_1.zwo.name: Week 4.1 - Micro Bursts
8wkRaceDay_4_1.zwo.description: Warm up for 10 minutes then perform 10 minutes of 10 secs full gas, 20 seconds recovery (barely any pressure on the pedals). Spin your legs for 5 minutes then perform 10 minutes of  20 seconds on / 40 off , recover for 5 minutes then a final 10 minute set of 10 secs on / 20 off , warm down for 10 minutes.
8wkRaceDay_4_1.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_4_2.zwo.name: Week 4.2 - Zone 1 Ride
8wkRaceDay_4_2.zwo.description:
This is predominantly a fat burning ride - low efforts which will build and create a far greater mitochondrial density. Which carries more oxygen to the working muscles later... more easy riding will support the hard workouts nicely.
High Cadence! Up Up Up! - LOW POWER - FAST BREATHING
8wkRaceDay_4_2.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_4_3.zwo.name: Week 4.3 - Split 2/3
8wkRaceDay_4_3.zwo.description: This session is best done indoors on the trainer (A split session, Zone 2 followed by Zone 3). Watch the rpm's change to activate different energy systems and work the legs and lungs.  A cardio workout followed by a leg workout. No recovery between the efforts, so straight into the Zone 3 block from the 30 mins @ zone 2
8wkRaceDay_4_3.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_4_4.zwo.name: Week 4.4 - Z6 Intervals
8wkRaceDay_4_4.zwo.description: Best done on the turbo. Start with 15 min warm up. Then perform 10 minutes of 30 seconds on @ Upper Zone 6  followed by 30 seconds off @ Upper Zone 2. Spin your legs easily for 10 minutes then repeat the 30/30 set . Today is a hard session so make sure you stay fuelled and hydrated throughout the day.
8wkRaceDay_4_4.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_5_1.zwo.name: Week 5.1 - Micro Bursts
8wkRaceDay_5_1.zwo.description: Warm up for 10 minutes then perform 10 minutes of 10 secs full gas, 20 seconds recovery (barely any pressure on the pedals). Spin your legs for 5 minutes then perform 10 minutes of  20 seconds on / 40 off , recover for 5 minutes then a final 10 minute set of 10 secs on / 20 off , warm down for 10 minutes.
8wkRaceDay_5_1.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_5_2.zwo.name: Week 5.2 - Cadence Change Efforts
8wkRaceDay_5_2.zwo.description: Start with a 10 minute warm up - Zone 1. Then 40 minutes Zone 2, but for the first 20 seconds of each and every minute, lift your cadence to 110 rpm - whilst maintaining the same power. So lower the resistence/gear and raise your cadence. 10 min cool down
8wkRaceDay_5_2.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_5_3.zwo.name: Week 5.3 - Strength Endurance
8wkRaceDay_5_3.zwo.description: This session is best done indoors on the trainer (A split session, Zone 2 followed by Zone 3). If short for time, drop the Zone 2 effort and go straight into the SE effort from the warm-up.
8wkRaceDay_5_3.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_5_4.zwo.name: Week 5.4 - Z6 Intervals
8wkRaceDay_5_4.zwo.description: Best done on the turbo. Start with 15 min warm up. Then perform 10 minutes of 30 seconds on @ Upper Zone 6  followed by 30 seconds off @ Upper Zone 2. Spin your legs easily for 10 minutes then repeat the 30/30 set. Today is a hard session so make sure you stay fuelled and hydrated throughout the day.
8wkRaceDay_5_4.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_6_1.zwo.name: Week 6.1 - Micro Bursts
8wkRaceDay_6_1.zwo.description: Warm up for 10 minutes then perform 10 minutes of 10 secs full gas, 20 seconds recovery (barely any pressure on the pedals). Spin your legs for 5 minutes then perform 10 minutes of  20 seconds on / 40 off , recover for 5 minutes then a final 10 minute set of 10 secs on / 20 off , warm down for 10 minutes.
8wkRaceDay_6_1.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_6_2.zwo.name: Week 6.2 - Z2 Cadence Changes
8wkRaceDay_6_2.zwo.description: Start with a 10 minute warm up - Zone 1. Then 30 minutes Zone 2, but for the first 20 seconds of each and every minute, lift your cadence to 110 rpm - whilst maintaining the same power. So lower the resistence/gear and raise your cadence. 10 min cool down
8wkRaceDay_6_2.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_6_3.zwo.name: Week 6.3 - Strength Endurance
8wkRaceDay_6_3.zwo.description: This session is best done indoors on the trainer (A split session, Zone 2 followed by Zone 3). If short for time, drop the Zone 2 effort and go straight into the SE effort from the warm-up.
8wkRaceDay_6_3.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_6_4.zwo.name: Week 6.4 - Z6 Intervals
8wkRaceDay_6_4.zwo.description: Start with 15 min warm up. Then perform 10 minutes of 30 seconds on @ Upper Zone 6  followed by 30 seconds off @ Upper Zone 2. Spin your legs easily for 10 minutes then repeat the 30/30 set. Today is a hard session so make sure you stay fuelled and hydrated throughout the day.
8wkRaceDay_6_4.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_7_1.zwo.name: Week 7.1 - Micro Bursts
8wkRaceDay_7_1.zwo.description: Warm up for 10 minutes then perform 10 minutes of 10 secs full gas, 20 seconds recovery (barely any pressure on the pedals). Spin your legs for 5 minutes then perform 10 minutes of  20 seconds on / 40 off, recover for 5 minutes then a final 10 minute set of 10 secs on / 20 off, warm down for 10 minutes.
8wkRaceDay_7_1.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_7_2.zwo.name: Week 7.2 - Z2 Cadence Changes
8wkRaceDay_7_2.zwo.description: Start with a 10 minute warm up - Zone 1. Then 20 minutes Zone 2, but for the first 20 seconds of each and every minute, lift your cadence to 110 rpm - whilst maintaining the same power. So lower the resistence/gear and raise your cadence. 10 min cool down.
8wkRaceDay_7_2.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_7_3.zwo.name: Week 7.3 - Strength Endurance
8wkRaceDay_7_3.zwo.description: This session is best done indoors on the trainer (A split session, Zone 2 followed by Zone 3). If short for time, drop the Zone 2 effort and go straight into the SE effort from the warm-up.
8wkRaceDay_7_3.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_7_4.zwo.name: Week 7.4 - Taper Intervals
8wkRaceDay_7_4.zwo.description: 15 min easy warm up. Taper intervals are to be 90 sec in duration. Not too hard, but slightly above 10 mile TT power. Recover @ Z1 for 3 min.
8wkRaceDay_7_4.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_8_1.zwo.name: Week 8.1 - Taper Intervals
8wkRaceDay_8_1.zwo.description: 15 min easy warm up. Taper intervals are to be 90 sec in duration. Not too hard, but slightly above 10 mile TT power. Recover @ Z1 for 3 min.
8wkRaceDay_8_1.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_8_2.zwo.name: Week 8.2 - Taper Intervals
8wkRaceDay_8_2.zwo.description: 15 min easy warm up. Taper intervals are to be 90 sec in duration. Not too hard, but slightly above 10 mile TT power. Recover @ Z1 for 3 min.
8wkRaceDay_8_2.zwo.author: trainSharp

8wkRaceDay_8_3.zwo.name: Week 8.3 - PRE-RACE DAY SPIN
8wkRaceDay_8_3.zwo.description: Practice your warm up routine. 10 mins Zone 1, 5 mins Zone 2, 5 mins Z3, 5 mins upper zone 4, 5 mins Zone 1. 3 x 30 second efforts at Zone 6 with 2 min recovery.
8wkRaceDay_8_3.zwo.author: trainSharp

10_The_Rollercoaster.zwo.name: Week 3.2 - The Rollercoaster
10_The_Rollercoaster.zwo.description:
This Rollercoaster session aims to replicate the demands of a mountain bike ride / event. 

Mountain biking generally involves far more variations in effort compared with road riding - so plenty of surges and time spent being over geared!

We touch upon all of these aspects in todays session, as we complete two blocks of alternating intensity, with top end Zone 6 surges thrown in there to replicate the demands of having to get up and over a steep bank or technical section. Feel free to get out of the saddle during the max efforts if you need to.

We also have a 12 minute Sweet Spot effort in the middle, to help continue to develop our endurance.
10_The_Rollercoaster.zwo.author: Matt Rowe (Rowe & King)

11_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.name: Week 3.3 - Unstructured Structure - Free Ride
11_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.description:
Welcome to another session in Zwift's MTB Workout Series! Today, you should get out and ride IRL to practice your technical skills. 

Mountain biking requires a huge amount of skill, and you can make significant improvements in your overall MTB ability without getting fitter and stronger, but by getting more skillful! 

If you are unable to get out IRL - you can complete this Zwift 'Free Ride'. Within the session, you should have ERG Mode on and let the terrain dictate your effort. 

On the climbs, reduce your cadence to 60rpm to work on strength, and go for all the sprints in game.

If riding IRL, aim to get over 2 hours of riding in.
11_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.author: Matt Rowe

12_The__Grind__Finale_.zwo.name: Week 4.1 - The 'Grind' Finale
12_The__Grind__Finale_.zwo.description:
This session aims to replicate the demands of a mountain bike ride / event. 

Mountain biking generally involves far more variations in effort compared with road riding - so plenty of surges and time spent being over geared! We also spend a lot of time 'on and off' the power, so short spells going  hard to get over an obstacle, followed by a freewheel or very low power on a descent or little dip.

We touch upon all of these aspects in todays session, as we start off alternating every 30 seconds between riding hard at a low cadence, and riding easy - as if we are riding through an undulating single track. Then we make a ramp in effort, which finishes with a 30 second near max effort up a steep, rocky banking!
12_The__Grind__Finale_.zwo.author: Matt Rowe (Rowe & King)

13_Over-Under_s_MTB_Style.zwo.name: Week 4.2 - Over-Under's, MTB Style
13_Over-Under_s_MTB_Style.zwo.description:
Todays workout is a very famous 'Over - Under' session, where we repeatedly ride over and under our threshold.

We will complete 2 x 15 minute blocks, each alternating between 'over' Zone 3 (80% of FTP) and 'under' Zone 4 (102% of FTP). 

Critically, the over sections are to be completed at a relatively low cadence of 70rpm. This is to give the session a strength endurance focus - ensuring we get used to producing not only high power, but also high crank torque, to support us in those sections of a mountain bike race where we have to momentarily freewheel, and are asked to produce huge crank torque from 0rpm!

We stimulate lactic acid production during the 'over' efforts, and we then try to recover, whilst still producing a moderate effort during the 'under' phase. Think of the 'over' as a technical part of a climb, whilst the under is climbing on a fire road or through a field!
13_Over-Under_s_MTB_Style.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

14_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.name: Week 4.3 - Unstructured Structure - Free Ride
14_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.description:
Welcome to another session in Zwift's MTB Workout Series! Today, you should get out and ride IRL to practice your technical skills. 

Mountain biking requires a huge amount of skill, and you can make significant improvements in your overall MTB ability without getting fitter and stronger, but by getting more skillful! 

If you are unable to get out IRL - you can complete this Zwift 'Free Ride'. Within the session, you should have ERG Mode on and let the terrain dictate your effort. 

On the climbs, reduce your cadence to 60rpm to work on strength, and go for all the sprints in game.

If riding IRL, aim to get over 2 hours of riding in.
14_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.author: Matt Rowe

15_Lumpy_Ramps.zwo.name: Week 4.4 - Lumpy Ramps
15_Lumpy_Ramps.zwo.description:
This session aims to replicate the demands of a mountain bike ride / event, by constantly changing the intensity at which we ride at! Not only does the power demand change, but so does your cadence.

Half of the 'ramp up's' are to be completed at a low cadence of 65rpm, whilst the other half are at your chosen cadence. Meanwhile, the 'ramp down's' are to be completed at a more familiar cadence of 85rpm.

The efforts we complete today are typical of a tough mountain bike ride / race, where you could be riding through any sort of terrain that has varying terrain!
15_Lumpy_Ramps.zwo.author: Matt Rowe (Rowe & King)

16_Saw_Legs.zwo.name: Week 4.5 - Saw Legs
16_Saw_Legs.zwo.description:
This session aims to develop your endurance by completing 3 blocks of 15 minutes around Zone 3, made up of short ramps to add in the constant variation in effort involved in mountain biking! There are also a few sprints thrown in there too, to simulate navigating across a technical uphill section. 

Additionally, the middle ramp within each block is to be completed at a low cadence, of 65rpm.
16_Saw_Legs.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

17_24_Shots_to_Fire.zwo.name: Week 5.1 - 24 Shots to Fire
17_24_Shots_to_Fire.zwo.description:
This workout really works your top end - your anaerobic capacity, which is your ability to make really hard efforts.

In mountain biking, to get up a short steep climb, or to get through some mud or over roots, the best way is to do it quickly - lots of power for a short period of time.

This session gets our anaerobic energy systems firing, as we make repeated 30 second efforts which increase in intensity through the blocks.

Don't be discouraged if your power drops throughout the blocks. You'll burn a lot of matches as you progress through the session, so just try and hold on as long as you can as you will still benefit from the effort.

In the same fashion - don't go out too hard! This is a fairly long session, so in the first block, just do what you need to do, 140% of FTP and no more.
17_24_Shots_to_Fire.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

18_6_Bombs_to_Drop.zwo.name: Week 5.2 - 6 Bombs to Drop
18_6_Bombs_to_Drop.zwo.description:
This workout can be likened to a mountain bike race with a hard start - a steady middle and a hard finish as we complete 2 blocks of efforts at 110% of FTP (Zone 5 - Vo2 Max), with an 8 minute block of Zone 3 (80% of FTP) in the middle. 

We are going to complete the first block of the Zone 5 efforts at a low cadence (65rpm) to simulate being stuck on a really steep section, where you are having to navigate around rocks.

We will complete the second block of efforts at your chosen cadence, which should feel a lot easier, and certainly less demanding of your muscular strength!
18_6_Bombs_to_Drop.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

19_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.name: Week 5.3 - Unstructured Structure - Free Ride
19_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.description:
Welcome to another session in the Dirt Destroyer Workout Series! Today, you should get out and ride IRL to practice your technical skills. 

Mountain biking requires a huge amount of skill, and you can make significant improvements in your overall MTB ability without getting fitter and stronger, but by getting more skillful! 

If you are unable to get out IRL - you can complete this Zwift 'Free Ride'. Within the session, you should have ERG Mode on and let the terrain dictate your effort. 

On the climbs, reduce your cadence to 60rpm to work on strength, and go for all the sprints in game.

If riding IRL, aim to get over 2 hours of riding in.
19_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.author: Matt Rowe

1_Back_to_Basics.zwo.name: Week 1.1 - Back to Basics
1_Back_to_Basics.zwo.description:
This is the very first session of the Dirt Destroyer, which takes us back to basics and focuses on developing your endurance and aerobic conditioning which are fundamental attributes for anyone looking to train hard, hold their form and perform in a mountain bike event.

We are going to push ourselves right up to our threshold, by completing 6 efforts, split in to two blocks of 3 efforts (85%, 95% and 100% of our FTP). The first effort within each block alternates between your chosen cadence and a low cadence of 65rpm. As the intensity of each effort goes up, the volume goes down!
You're going to need to use a Cadence Sensor to make the most of these workouts
1_Back_to_Basics.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

20_Two_Timer.zwo.name: Week 5.4 - Two Timer
20_Two_Timer.zwo.description:
Todays workout contains some ramped efforts, at varying cadences.

We will complete 2 x 15 minute blocks, each containing a two consecutive ramps, with the first at a low cadence of 60rpm, followed by a short block of 'Over-Unders' where we tip above and under your threshold before a big 30 second push at the end.

We spend a lot of time today around your threshold, but critically not AT threshold, which is more aligned to the demands of mountain biking.
20_Two_Timer.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

21_Really_Saw_Legs.zwo.name: Week 5.5 - Really Saw Legs
21_Really_Saw_Legs.zwo.description:
This session aims to develop your endurance by completing 3 blocks of 15 minutes around Sweet Spot, made up of short ramps to add in the constant variation in effort involved in mountain biking! There are also a few sprints thrown in there too, to simulate navigating across a technical uphill section. 

Additionally, the middle ramp within each block is to be completed at a low cadence, of 65rpm. Todays powers are slightly higher than last week - a sign of progression!
21_Really_Saw_Legs.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

22_Max_O_clock.zwo.name: Week 6.1 - Max O'clock
22_Max_O_clock.zwo.description:
This workout really works your top end - your anaerobic capacity, which is your ability to make really hard efforts.

Similar to last week, we are going to complete 3 blocks of effort. However this time, the duration of each effort will decrease through each block, whilst the intensity significantly increases! The third block is full gas, as you claw your way to the end of each effort or rocky ascent!

In mountain biking, to get up a short steep climb, or to get through some mud or over roots, the best way is to do it quickly - lots of power for a short period of time. Let's do this!
22_Max_O_clock.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

23_6_Strength_Bombs.zwo.name: Week 6.2 - 6 Strength Bombs
23_6_Strength_Bombs.zwo.description:
This workout can be likened to a race with a hard start - a steady middle and a hard finish as we complete 2 blocks of efforts at 110% of FTP (Zone 5 - Vo2 Max), with a 10 minute block of Zone 3 (82% of FTP) in the middle. 

We are going to complete all 6 of the Zone 5 efforts at a low cadence (65rpm) to simulate being stuck on a really steep section, where you are having to navigate around rocks. You will likely produce a fairly erratic pedaling style as your power output varies significantly from pedal stroke to pedal stroke!

You will notice the second block of efforts is a lot harder, as we will have the first block of efforts already in our legs - plus the 10 minute aerobic effort too.
23_6_Strength_Bombs.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

24_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.name: Week 6.3 - Unstructured Structure - Free Ride
24_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.description:
Today, you should get out and ride IRL to practice your technical skills. 

Mountain biking requires a huge amount of skill, and you can make significant improvements in your overall MTB ability without getting fitter and stronger, but by getting more skilful! 

If you are unable to get out IRL - you can complete this Zwift 'Free Ride'. Within the session, you should have ERG Mode on and let the terrain dictate your effort. 

On the climbs, reduce your cadence to 60rpm to work on strength, and go for all the sprints in game.

If riding IRL, aim to get over 2 hours of riding in.
24_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zw.author: Matt Rowe

25_The_Egyptian_.zwo.name: Week 6.4 - The Egyptian
25_The_Egyptian_.zwo.description:
This is one of the final workouts within the Dirt Destroyer which is a pyramid style workout, hence "The Egyptian".

This is an all round session which will help to boost your endurance, but also your strength as we hit the peak of the pyramid. Here we complete a 1 minute effort at 109% of FTP, critically at 70rpm which really draws on your strength and is what really makes this part of the pyramid a challenge. 

This workout keeps things interesting by changing the intensity and the monotony of a steady state effort.
25_The_Egyptian_.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

26_130__Of_FTP_Hangers.zwo.name: Week 6.5 - 130% of FTP Hangers
26_130__Of_FTP_Hangers.zwo.description:
Congratulations on reaching the final workout in the Dirt Destroyer. 

This sessions aims to develop your Anaerobic Capacity - your ability to produce a lot of power for a short period of time. We complete efforts at 135% of FTP, whilst reducing the amount of rest we get between each effort - meaning each effort will get progressively harder.

If you look at the demands of Mountain Biking, you are frequently making efforts up around 135%+ of your FTP, to tackle obstacles and get up steep climbs. The effort durations vary significantly, which is what we are looking to train today - your ability to produce big power, once already fatigued, on limited recovery!
26_130__Of_FTP_Hangers.zwo.author: M.Rowe (Rowe & King)

2_70rpm_Strength_Ramps.zwo.name: Week 1.2 - 70rpm Strength Ramps
2_70rpm_Strength_Ramps.zwo.description:
Welcome to another session of the Dirt Destroyer, which contains two ramped efforts, at a low cadence. Each ramp starts at 65% of your FTP and ramps up, so get ready to grit your teeth a little towards the end of each ramp.

The low cadence provides a strength element to the session, which is fundamental to mountain biking. Just think about all the times you are caught at a low speed, having to get over a rocky or muddy section, which really draws upon your strength.
2_70rpm_Strength_Ramps.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

3_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zwo.name: Week 1.3 - Unstructured Structure - Free Ride
3_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zwo.description:
Welcome to another session of the Dirt Destroyer! Today, you should get out and ride IRL to practice your technical skills. 

Mountain biking requires a huge amount of skill, and you can make significant improvements in your overall MTB ability without getting fitter and stronger, but by getting more skilful! 

If you are unable to get out IRL - you can complete this Zwift 'Free Ride'. Within the session, you should have ERG Mode on and let the terrain dictate your effort. 

On the climbs, reduce your cadence to 60rpm to work on strength, and go for all the sprints in game.

IF riding IRL, aim to ride for over 2 hours.
3_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

4_Surge_to_the_Max.zwo.name: Week 1.4 - Surge to the Max
4_Surge_to_the_Max.zwo.description:
This session aims to develop your ability to make big surges in effort, to overcome tricky sections on a mountain bike, i.e. a really muddy / boggy section, or super steep and rocky climb, where you need to ride almost max effort just to get up it!

Often, during these technical sections, you are forced to ride at a low cadence of around 65rpm of lower, which is is where todays 1 minute efforts take place. After a short ramp, you will complete a 1 minute max effort at 65rpm - grind it out!
4_Surge_to_the_Max.zwo.author: Matt Rowe (Rowe & King)

5_Varying_Threshold.zwo.name: Week 2.1 - Varying Threshold
5_Varying_Threshold.zwo.description:
Today's Varying Threshold session is centered around your threshold, but unlike for a traditional training plan for the road, there is some specific cadences to ride at for some of the efforts, where we alternate between your chosen / go to cadence and a low cadence as we often end up riding at on a mountain bike. 

We are going to push ourselves right up to our threshold, by completing 6 efforts, split in to two blocks of 3 efforts (90%, 95% and 100% of our FTP). As the intensity goes up, the volume goes down so this session is definitely manageable and is a nice building block rather than leaving you totally exhausted for tomorrow. 

The first block will alternate between your chosen cadence and a low cadence of 65rpm.
5_Varying_Threshold.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

6_65rpm_Strength_Ramps.zwo.name: Week 2.2 - 65rpm Strength Ramps
6_65rpm_Strength_Ramps.zwo.description:
Welcome to another session of the Dirt Destroyer, which contains two ramped efforts, at a low cadence. Each ramp starts at 65% of your FTP and ramps up, so get ready to grit your teeth a little towards the end of each ramp. This session progresses a little from last week, as the cadence is slightly lower, so the session is harder!

The low cadence provides a strength element to the session, which is fundamental to mountain biking. Just think about all the times you are caught at a low speed, having to get over a rocky or muddy section, which really draws upon your strength.
6_65rpm_Strength_Ramps.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

7_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zwo.name: Week 2.3 - Unstructured Structure - Free Ride
7_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zwo.description:
Welcome to another Dirt Destroyer session! Today, you should get out and ride IRL to practice your technical skills. 

Mountain biking requires a huge amount of skill, and you can make significant improvements in your overall MTB ability without getting fitter and stronger, but by getting more skilful! 

If you are unable to get out IRL - you can complete this Zwift 'Free Ride'. Within the session, you should have ERG Mode on and let the terrain dictate your effort. 

On the climbs, reduce your cadence to 60rpm to work on strength, and go for all the sprints in game.

IF riding IRL, aim to ride for over 2 hours.
7_Unstructured_Structure_-_Free_Ride.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

8_Strength_Surges.zwo.name: Week 2.4 - Strength Surges
8_Strength_Surges.zwo.description:
This session aims to replicate the demands of a mountain bike ride / event. 

Mountain biking generally involves far more variations in effort compared with road riding - so plenty of surges and time spent being over geared!

We touch upon all of these aspects in todays session, as we ramp our effort up at a low cadence to replicate climbing a technical section, picking our way around rocks, before a Z4 effort on a fire road, before heading back in to the forest and up a really steep technical section where once again we are forced to ride at an uncomfortably low cadence, in the saddle!
8_Strength_Surges.zwo.author: Matt Rowe (Rowe & King)

9_Threshold_Scatter.zwo.name: Week 3.1 - Threshold Scatter
9_Threshold_Scatter.zwo.description:
Today's session is centered around your developing your threshold and critically, your strength!

We will spend plenty of time alternating between your chosen / go to cadence and a low cadence as we often end up riding at on a mountain bike. This is one of the key differences between road riding and mountain bike - the constant change in effort. Even riding up a steady gradient, on a mountain bike your power will vary significantly as you navigate over and around rocks, roots, and other obstacles!

This session aims to further develop your ability to make these changes in effort more comfortably.
9_Threshold_Scatter.zwo.author: Matt Rowe

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_1_1.xml.name: Week 1.1 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_1_1.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_1_2.xml.name: Week 1.2 - Strength
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_1_2.xml.description: Strength training: A certain repetition of short and maximal efforts with the goal to increase neuromuscular recruitment and maximum specific strength.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_1_3.xml.name: Week 1.3 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_1_3.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_1_4.xml.name: Week 1.4 - Tempo
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_1_4.xml.description: Tempo training: The goal of this training is to spend time in Zone 3, an intensity where the use of sugar and fats as fuel is equal. Time spent in this zone increases muscle glycogen storages.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_2_1.xml.name: Week 2.1 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_2_1.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_2_2.xml.name: Week 2.2 - Strength
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_2_2.xml.description: Strength training: A certain repetition of short and maximal efforts with the goal to increase neuromuscular recruitment and maximum specific strength.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_2_3.xml.name: Week 2.3 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_2_3.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_2_4.xml.name: Week 2.4 - Tempo
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_2_4.xml.description: Tempo training: the goal of this training is to spend time in Zone 3 at an intensity where the use of sugar and fats as fuel is equal. Time spent in this zone increases muscle glycogen storages.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_2_5.xml.name: Week 2.5 - Active Recovery
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_2_5.xml.description: This optional training can be done in any other day of the week, not necessarily as last day.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_3_1.xml.name: Week 3.1 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_3_1.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_3_2.xml.name: Week 3.2 - Strength
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_3_2.xml.description: Strength training: A certain repetition of short and maximal efforts with the goal to increase neuromuscular recruitment and maximum specific strength.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_3_3.xml.name: Week 3.3 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_3_3.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_3_4.xml.name: Week 3.4 - Tempo
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_3_4.xml.description: Tempo training: The goal of this training is to spend time in Zone 3 at an intensity where the use of sugar and fats as fuel is equal. Time spent in this zone increases muscle glycogen storages.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_4_1.xml.name: Week 4.1 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_4_1.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_4_2.xml.name: Week 4.2 - Intermittent
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_4_2.xml.description: Intermittent: This training is a way to introduce short high intensity riding alternating it with short recovery, allowing the rider to recover and accumulate time at an intensity that would be difficult to maintain if ridden consecutively.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_4_3.xml.name: Week 4.3 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_4_3.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_4_4.xml.name: Week 4.4 - Tempo
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_4_4.xml.description: Tempo training: The goal of this training is to spend time in Zone 3 at an intensity where the use of sugar and fats as fuel is equal. Time spent in this zone increases muscle glycogen storages.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_4_5.xml.name: Week 4.5 - Active Recovery
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_4_5.xml.description: This optional training can be done in any other day of the week, not necessarily as last day. Also, open the possibility to it in a fasted state.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_5_1.xml.name: Week 5.1 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_5_1.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_5_2.xml.name: Week 5.2 - Threshold Development
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_5_2.xml.description: Threshold Development: This training is targeting the increase in lactate threshold (FTP) with relatively short intervals at intensity of Zone 4.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_5_3.xml.name: Week 5.3 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_5_3.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_5_4.xml.name: Week 5.4 - Threshold Development
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_5_4.xml.description: Threshold Development: This training is targeting the increase in lactate threshold (FTP) with relatively short intervals at intensity of Zone 4.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_5_5.xml.name: Week 5.5 - Active Recovery
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_5_5.xml.description: This optional training can be done in any other day of the week, not necessarily as last day. Also, open the possibility to it in a fasted state.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_6_1.xml.name: Week 6.1 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_6_1.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_6_2.xml.name: Week 6.2 - Threshold Development
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_6_2.xml.description: Threshold Development: This training is targeting the increase in lactate threshold (FTP) with relatively short intervals at intensity of Zone 4.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_6_3.xml.name: Week 6.3 - Foundation
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_6_3.xml.description: Foundation training: Relatively low intensity ride with goal of spending a large proportion of the ride into Endurance Zone 2.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_6_4.xml.name: Week 6.4 - Threshold Development
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_6_4.xml.description: Threshold Development: This training is targeting the increase in lactate threshold (FTP) with relatively short intervals at intensity of Zone 4.

pinotti_ftp_builder_short_6_5.xml.name: Week 6.5 - Flexible Free Ride
pinotti_ftp_builder_short_6_5.xml.description: Ride as you feel. No intervals. Go hard if you feel to.

BriskBurn.zwo.name: Week 1.1 - Brisk Burn
BriskBurn.zwo.description: Every journey starts with a single step, and we'll start this fitness journey with a 16min workout. The only focus for you today is to have fun working through the power zones! We'll start with a quick warm-up, then get into the workout intervals, which feature various lengths and intensities. All aboard the train going down the fast track to fitness!
BriskBurn.zwo.author: Zwift

CalorieCrush.zwo.name: Week 2.2 - Calorie Crush
CalorieCrush.zwo.description: Back at it with another super fun workout! We're going to push the workout length up again today to 25min too! We'll start with a warm-up, then dive into quick 20sec long intervals at various intensities. Fear not, though, this workout may be high-intensity, but it will crush your daily calorie count!
CalorieCrush.zwo.author: Zwift

Emily_s_Short_Mix.zwo.name: Week 4.2 - Emily's Short Mix
Emily_s_Short_Mix.zwo.description: This workout is designed to get maximal results from minimal time. You'll go through three sets of intervals that ramp the intensity, with each series getting both harder and longer. It won't be easy, but at least it'll be over soon! CRUSH IT TODAY!
Emily_s_Short_Mix.zwo.author: E.Mullen

FlashBurn.zwo.name: Week 3.1 - Flash Burn
FlashBurn.zwo.description: This is the last step before we hit the 30min long workouts; look at the progress you've made already! You should be proud of yourself for sticking it out and showing up each week! Today's 28min high-intensity workout is perfect for getting in your daily burn. This session is 6 rounds of 40, 20, and 10sec down the ladder, with a 10sec recovery at the bottom, then 10, 20, and 40 seconds back up the ladder. The efforts increase as the durations get shorter, so get ready to push yourself further today!
FlashBurn.zwo.author: Zwift

InstantInferno.zwo.name: Week 1.2 - Instant Inferno
InstantInferno.zwo.description: Let's keep the consistency going with a quick 18-minute high-intensity workout. After the warm-up, the session features 30sec of work, with 30sec of rest at various intensities and recoveries. Let's send some calories into the fiery inferno!
InstantInferno.zwo.author: Zwift

Lavendar_Unicorn.zwo.name: Week 3.2 - Lavendar Unicorn
Lavendar_Unicorn.zwo.description: For the first of our 3, 30min workouts of the plan, we'll spend time riding under and over your FTP. This 30-minute workout requires hard work at nearly every phase, but you are strong and can get it done! Doing these kinds of workouts builds up your strength and ability to bounce back after hard efforts. You'll also feel mentally stronger and more resilient.
Lavendar_Unicorn.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

TwentyTorch.zwo.name: Week 2.1 - Twenty Torch
TwentyTorch.zwo.description: You can do anything for 20min, right!? Good! Because this 20min high-intensity workout will torch your daily calories. The session is 3 rounds of 60, 45, 30, and 15sec efforts. Each round will get a little more intense - so get ready to bring your best effort in the final round!
TwentyTorch.zwo.author: Zwift

Wave_Rider.zwo.name: Week 4.1 - Wave Rider
Wave_Rider.zwo.description: They call it the "Wave Rider" because the workout graphic looks like waves. You'll ramp up slowly to a short power burst, then ride the same power wave again four times. No surfboard required, but make sure to keep your head above water.
Wave_Rider.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney | GC Coaching

ZwiftFondo_Wk1_Wo1.zwo.name: Week 1.1 - Welcome Workout
ZwiftFondo_Wk1_Wo1.zwo.description: Introductory workout for those joining Zwift's Bambino Fondo training plan. For the Bambino Fondo training plan, we will have three workouts a week: two interval workouts of about 50min each during the week and a long ride on the weekend.
ZwiftFondo_Wk1_Wo1.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk1_Wo2.zwo.name: Week 1.2 - Introductory Intervals
ZwiftFondo_Wk1_Wo2.zwo.description:
This workout consists of two rounds of progressively harder - but shorter - intervals in the sub-threshold zones. 
    
    Workout consists of a 5min warm-up, two rounds of 4min at 65%, 2min easy, 3:30 at 81%, 2min easy, 2:30 at 95%, 2min easy, and then a 3min cool-down.
ZwiftFondo_Wk1_Wo2.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk1_Wo3.zwo.name: Week 1.3 - The Long Ride
ZwiftFondo_Wk1_Wo3.zwo.description: Long base ride to give the endurance needed to tackle the Zwift Fondo. We will increase the overall duration of this workout each week while maintaining a similar structure for the workouts. The focus here is on foundational fitness which will support the shorter and harder mid-week intervals.
ZwiftFondo_Wk1_Wo3.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk2_Wo1.zwo.name: Week 2.1 - Long Tempo
ZwiftFondo_Wk2_Wo1.zwo.description: Long tempo intervals here to get you used to sustained higher effort that will help power you up and over the longer climbs.
ZwiftFondo_Wk2_Wo1.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk2_Wo2.zwo.name: Week 2.2 - Make A Break For It
ZwiftFondo_Wk2_Wo2.zwo.description: Work here on that top end speed just above threshold. If you want to make - or join - a breakaway, this is the sort of fitness you will need to make that happen.
ZwiftFondo_Wk2_Wo2.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk2_Wo3.zwo.name: Week 2.3 - The Long Ride
ZwiftFondo_Wk2_Wo3.zwo.description: Long base ride to give the endurance needed to tackle the Zwift Fondo. We will increase the overall duration of this workout each week while maintaining a similar structure for the workouts. The focus here is on foundational fitness which will support the shorter and harder mid-week intervals.
ZwiftFondo_Wk2_Wo3.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk3_Wo1.zwo.name: Week 3.1 - Step-Down Intervals
ZwiftFondo_Wk3_Wo1.zwo.description: The main work here is a long descending ladder that starts out above threshold and steps down in progressively longer intervals. When you're tired going over those final climbs, you can rely on the strength you've built up here.
ZwiftFondo_Wk3_Wo1.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk3_Wo2.zwo.name: Week 3.2 - Low-Cadence Intervals
ZwiftFondo_Wk3_Wo2.zwo.description: Focused low-cadence 3min intervals bracketing goal 90% FTP power. Build all while holding a good low cadence down in the 50s. Recovery with high cadence and still reasonable aerobic power. The power here shouldn't be a challenge... except for the cadence. If you can get comfortable generating your target race power with a firm cadence cap, it becomes a lot easier on race day when you can ride whatever cadence you choose. The cadence caps on the hard work are critical, so make sure not to cheat up and spin a bit faster to make it easier.
ZwiftFondo_Wk3_Wo2.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk3_Wo3.zwo.name: Week 3.3 - The Long Ride
ZwiftFondo_Wk3_Wo3.zwo.description: Long base ride to give the endurance needed to tackle the Zwift Fondo. This is the longest ride you will do in advance of taking on the Fondo. From here, you will taper to rest, recover, and sharpen up over the next week.
ZwiftFondo_Wk3_Wo3.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk4_Wo1.zwo.name: Week 4.1 - Taper Time
ZwiftFondo_Wk4_Wo1.zwo.description: The hard work is done! It is time to TAPER! Keep your muscles firing as we back off the load to let you recover and freshen up for the big day!
ZwiftFondo_Wk4_Wo1.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk4_Wo2.zwo.name: Week 4.2 - Taper Steady
ZwiftFondo_Wk4_Wo2.zwo.description: Keeping the rhythm flowing here. Some nice, light work just to keep things ticking over. Hold that rhythm right through to the Fondo!
ZwiftFondo_Wk4_Wo2.zwo.author: Zwift

ZwiftFondo_Wk4_Wo3.zwo.name: Week 4.3 - Final Sharpen
ZwiftFondo_Wk4_Wo3.zwo.description: One final tune-up to keep the legs sharp and the mind and body fresh before you take on your Fondo!
ZwiftFondo_Wk4_Wo3.zwo.author: Zwift

AvdB_Over_Under.zwo.name: Fun is Staying Cool
AvdB_Over_Under.zwo.description: Anna van der Breggen is arguably one of the most versatile riders of her generation. She excels by staying cool when others crumble under pressure. So, what better way to challenge your ability to embrace your inner Anna van der Breggen by doing some over/unders! Over/unders are great for improving your ability to surge hard again and again but not recovering fully in between. A perfect workout for one-day classics and stage race specialists - like Anna!
AvdB_Over_Under.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney

Geraint_Thomas_Climb.zwo.name: Fun is Flying Uphill
Geraint_Thomas_Climb.zwo.description: Steady tempo efforts are great, but by incorporating 30sec high-intensity efforts into them, you will improve your body's ability to work aerobically for longer periods of time. This helps the body adapt to the natural surges in climbing around hairpin corners or even following the increased pace after an attack. Today's sessions consists of 2 x 16min tempo efforts with a 30sec surge every 3.5min.
Geraint_Thomas_Climb.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney

MvdP_Anaerobic.zwo.name: Fun is Going Full Gas
MvdP_Anaerobic.zwo.description: Since he was a Junior, Mathieu van der Poel (MvdP) has been dominant in cyclocross and mountain biking, winning World titles in both. Now he also races at WorldTour level, winning stage races and Classics. He has an incredible ability to accelerate, seemingly at will, and keep extreme pressure on to break his competitors. This ability is called anaerobic capacity and is what today's workout will be focused on improving.
MvdP_Anaerobic.zwo.author: Shayne Gaffney

Climbing1.zwo.name: Seated & Standing
Climbing1.zwo.description:
These are designed to be done in the saddle for the first 2minutes, then stand and do the final 30 seconds out of the saddle and sprinting over the top of the hill. Short recoveries, to help improve your "repeatability" at the same time.   
Warm-up 10 minutes and then 3 x 1 minute fast pedaling drills >110rpm
Then do 5 minutes at tempo, followed by 10 x hill repeats.   Seated for 2 minutes, then out of the saddle as the resistance becomes harder. Recover for 2minutes and then cool-down
Climbing1.zwo.author: GCN

Climbing2.zwo.name: Hill Attacks
Climbing2.zwo.description:
Prepare the mind and body for hill attacks.  You are attacking up the hill at the front of the peloton and inflicting devastation upon the peloton.  Attack after attack, the peloton is getting blown apart by your relentless attacks.  
Warm-up for 10minutes and do 3 x 1minute fast pedaling drills>110rpm. A nice tempo pace for 5minutes and then do (10) x 1minute hill attacks.   Rest for 2 minutes between each.  Cool-down.
Climbing2.zwo.author: GCN

Climbing3.zwo.name: Vo2max
Climbing3.zwo.description:
This is designed to improve your Vo2max power, so you are ready for hard steep climbs and the big wattage needed to attack those hills. This workout has longer recoveries in order to focus on the maximum power produced for each interval. Really drill it on each. 
Warm up for 10minutes and then do 3 x 1minute fast pedaling drills.
Then get ready for 7 x 3minutes with 4 minutes between each at endurance pace recovering well.   
Cool-down.
Climbing3.zwo.author: GCN

Climbing4.zwo.name: Sweetspot w/ steeps
Climbing4.zwo.description: Riding at sweetspot, close to the edge of destruction, then having to attack hill after hill will make you stronger and ready for all that the spring classics have in store for you!   Warm-up 10 minutes with 3 x 1minute fast pedaling drills >110rpm and then ride at Sweetspot 88-93% of FTP for 35 minutes and every two minutes, do a 45 second hill interval at 130% of FTP, and recover back to sweetspot.  Get ready for these!   Cool-down.
Climbing4.zwo.author: GCN

Climbing5.zwo.name: Steeper & Steeper
Climbing5.zwo.description:
Sometimes the climbs get steeper and steeper as you get closer to the top.  This workout simulates the climbs of the spring classics that start out steep and get even steeper!
